This doesn't always mean the image is up to date right? I believe the app will hit this else statement if the image is not cached at all.
I suggest updating the log to be more clear or restructuring the if statements to separate the three cases to make it easier to follow:
1-image not cached
2-image cached and valid
3-image cached but expired

timeline.bodyText:
Do you think we can simplify that a bit by only storing the hash as key and the time as a value instead of saving the JSON in shared prefs?
currently, this is how the share prefs xml look like. We save the hash twice. I feel that is unesceasry
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8' standalone='yes' ?>
<map>
    <string name="935e06761f887b20a5a10242faaf6ecf">{"storedUrl":"\/data\/user\/0\/io.livio.sdltestsuite.app1\/cache\/sdl\/lock_screen_icon\/935e06761f887b20a5a10242faaf6ecf","lastUpdatedTime":1585600940171}</string>
</map>

Cannot we just store them like that? This way we don't even need to make s JSON.
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8' standalone='yes' ?>
<map>
    <string name="935e06761f887b20a5a10242faaf6ecf">1585600940171</string>
</map>

replies.author: RHenigan

timeline.bodyText:
I don't think that this is necessarily what we want to do here, unlike iOS. On iOS, all the image file information is contained in one file. So on iOS, when you clear the icon directory, the file went along with it. Here, if the directory is cleared, all the icon information remains in SharedPreferences. That means that attempting to retrieve an icon may fail and then we'll have a cascading set of retrieval failures because old data is contained in SharedPreferences that we know isn't accurate.
I can think of a few possibilities to solve this:

We don't clear the icon directory if an error occurs. This isn't aligned with iOS' mitigation strategy and has the possibility of leaving icons in the directory that are unused.
Instead of storing the data in separate SharedPreferences keys, use a single key, store the information in JSON and store the JSON in the SharedPreferences under that single key. Then when you clear the icon directory, you clear the JSON document as well.
timeline.author: joeljfischer

replies.author: RHenigan

replies.bodyText: If that clears all data about cached icons and their expiration dates, then yes, I believe it would.
